title: Opera Basics
description: Test your knowledge of the grand world of opera, from famous arias to legendary composers!

questions.question: Which Italian composer wrote 'La Traviata,' 'Aida,' and 'Rigoletto'?
questions.explanation: Giuseppe Verdi was one of the most influential opera composers of the 19th century. His works remain central to the standard opera repertoire worldwide.

questions.question: What is an 'aria' in opera?
options: A solo vocal piece for one singer
questions.explanation: An aria is a self-contained piece for one voice, usually expressing emotion or revealing character. Famous arias include 'Nessun Dorma' and 'La donna è mobile.'

questions.question: Which Puccini opera features the aria 'Nessun Dorma'?
questions.explanation: 'Nessun Dorma' is sung by the character Calaf in 'Turandot.' It became widely popular after Luciano Pavarotti performed it at the 1990 FIFA World Cup.

questions.question: In which country did opera originate around the year 1600?
questions.explanation: Opera originated in Italy, with 'Dafne' by Jacopo Peri (c. 1597) considered the first opera. Florence was the birthplace of the art form, created by a group called the Camerata.

questions.question: Which Mozart opera tells the story of a legendary seducer and features the 'Catalogue Aria'?
questions.explanation: 'Don Giovanni' (1787) dramatizes the exploits and downfall of the legendary Don Juan. The 'Catalogue Aria' lists Don Giovanni's numerous romantic conquests across Europe.

questions.question: What is the term for the text or script of an opera?
questions.explanation: A libretto (Italian for 'little book') is the text of an opera, including all sung and spoken words. The person who writes it is called a librettist.

questions.question: Which German composer created the four-opera cycle 'Der Ring des Nibelungen'?
questions.explanation: Richard Wagner composed 'The Ring Cycle' over 26 years. The four operas, performed over about 15 hours, draw on Norse mythology and premiered at the Bayreuth Festival in 1876.

questions.question: What type of voice is a soprano?
questions.explanation: Soprano is the highest vocal range, typically found in female singers. In opera, sopranos often sing the leading female roles, known as the prima donna.

questions.question: Which Bizet opera features a fiery gypsy woman working in a cigarette factory in Seville?
questions.explanation: Georges Bizet's 'Carmen' (1875) tells the tragic story of the free-spirited Carmen and the soldier Don José. It is one of the most frequently performed operas worldwide.

questions.question: What is a 'recitative' in opera?
options: Speech-like singing that advances the plot
The final chorus of an act
A duet between the lead characters
questions.explanation: Recitative is a style of singing that mimics the rhythms of natural speech. It is used to move the story forward between the more melodic arias and ensembles.

questions.question: Which famous tenor popularized opera for mainstream audiences with concerts like 'The Three Tenors'?
questions.explanation: Luciano Pavarotti, along with Plácido Domingo and José Carreras, formed 'The Three Tenors.' Pavarotti's charisma and powerful voice brought opera to millions of new listeners.

questions.question: In Puccini's 'La Bohème,' what is the setting of the story?
questions.explanation: 'La Bohème' (1896) follows the love story of the poet Rodolfo and the seamstress Mimì among struggling artists in Paris. It inspired the modern musical 'Rent.'

questions.question: What is the orchestral introduction played before the curtain rises called?
questions.explanation: An overture is the instrumental piece that opens an opera, often previewing themes and melodies that will appear later in the work. Some overtures have become popular concert pieces.

questions.question: Which Rossini opera is a comedic tale about a clever barber in Seville?
questions.explanation: 'The Barber of Seville' (1816) features the witty Figaro helping Count Almaviva woo the beautiful Rosina. Its lively overture is one of the most recognizable in all of opera.

questions.question: What does 'opera buffa' mean?
questions.explanation: 'Opera buffa' is Italian for comic opera. Originating in 18th-century Naples, it features everyday characters and humorous situations, in contrast to the serious 'opera seria.'
